image.altText: Damage to the wing of a plane after a collision

items.synopsis: Queensland Police Acting Superintendent Paul Ready said it incident was a "devastating loss of life".

title.children: Couple in their 60s who died after two planes collided north of Brisbane identified as David and Jan Maddern

image.altText: Stuart Broad looks back at the umpire while running as teammates celebrate behind him

items.synopsis: Australia is trying to go big in its first innings after sending England in to bat on day one of the final Ashes Test at the Oval. Follow live.

title.children: Australia's middle order collapses on day two at The Oval leaving England in command

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Smith loses his shape on another attempted slog and Jonny Bairstow tracks back and takes the catch easily in the end. Was that a slower ball from Woakes? It certainly seemed to trip up Smith. He's gone for 71 and will be kicking himself because he just got away with one, and then went for it again. Really trying his luck, but he doesn't escape this time. Australia is still 44 runs behind and now fresh out of specialist batters, leaving Pat Cummins and Todd Murphy with a job to do.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: STEVE SMITH HOLES OUT!!

children.content: Smith loses his shape on another attempted slog and Jonny Bairstow tracks back and takes the catch easily in the end.
Was that a slower ball from Woakes? It certainly seemed to trip up Smith.
He's gone for 71 and will be kicking himself because he just got away with one, and then went for it again. Really trying his luck, but he doesn't escape this time.
Australia is still 44 runs behind and now fresh out of specialist batters, leaving Pat Cummins and Todd Murphy with a job to do.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The former Aussie skipper has looked good out there and reaches another half-century with a stylish drive down the ground for four. He's done a huge job her, but Australia needs even more from him.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Steve Smith reaches 50!

children.content: The former Aussie skipper has looked good out there and reaches another half-century with a stylish drive down the ground for four. He's done a huge job her, but Australia needs even more from him.

props.alt: Australia batter Steve Smith completes a drive during an Ashes Test.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Well, could that session have gone much worse for Australia? Probably not. Five wickets lost, England rediscovering their mojo with a ball that is doing plenty, swinging and seaming all over the joint. Joe Root has only bowled six overs but has done a job for his skipper to get a wicket and hold up an end for a bit, but the real stars have been Stuart Broad and Jimmy Anderson with their excellent start - plus the undervalued Chris Woakes and hardworking Mark Wood. It's still all to play for, but Australia needs to get a fair bit closer to England's first innings total - they still trail by 97.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Tea: Australia 7-186 (Smith 40, Cummins 1)

children.content: Well, could that session have gone much worse for Australia?
Five wickets lost, England rediscovering their mojo with a ball that is doing plenty, swinging and seaming all over the joint.

Joe Root has only bowled six overs but has done a job for his skipper to get a wicket and hold up an end for a bit, but the real stars have been Stuart Broad and Jimmy Anderson with their excellent start - plus the undervalued Chris Woakes and hardworking Mark Wood.
It's still all to play for, but Australia needs to get a fair bit closer to England's first innings total - they still trail by 97.

image.altText: A man punches the air in celebration

items.synopsis: Carlton claims its sixth win in a row with a dynamic display against the Magpies, with Charlie Curnow booting six goals for the winners. Check out all the stats, scores, and latest news here.

title.children: Carlton's stunning march to September continues as Curnow brilliance downs Pies

image.altText: An aerial view of streets in suburban Melbourne, on a sunny day.

items.synopsis: Some suburbs are now seeing as much as a 14.4 per cent growth in median house value.

title.children: Some Australian suburbs are experiencing another property market boom. Is yours one of them?

image.altText: Shane Tuck breaking past Ben Warren carrying an AFL ball.

items.synopsis: Richmond footy player Shane Tuck "pushed through hell" with a brain injury, his sister tells an inquest. Meanwhile the AFL says a protective helmet is still in the concept phase.

title.children: AFL player Shane Tuck 'pushed through hell', his sister tells inquest

image.altText: England female football player is surrounded by medics, while sitting on a stretcher

items.synopsis: The Lionesses are on the cusp of qualifying for the Round of 16 with a victory in Sydney, but another injury blow has soured their win.

title.children: England beat Denmark 1-0 but win soured by injury to star Walsh, China overcomes Haiti

image.altText: A faint blue flame is burning from a gas element on a stainless steel cooktop

items.synopsis: The Victorian government will ban gas connections to new homes and residential subdivisions from January 1 next year.

title.children: Victoria bans gas connections in new homes from 2024

image.altText: An SES rescue boat with three crew traverse floods in Maribyrnong, Melbourne.

items.synopsis: Melbourne Water discussed "tweaking" the parameters of the Maribyrnong River flood review based on input from its insurer, documents reveal

title.children: Melbourne Water consulted insurer, government on independent flood review, documents reveal

image.altText: A partially overturned boat washed up on the bank of a body of water.

items.synopsis: Typhoon Doksuri regained super typhoon strength in its final approach to south-eastern China after pummelling Taiwan and the northern Philippines with rain and strong winds that led to the capsize of a ferry in which at least 26 people died.

title.children: Super typhoon makes landfall in China after ferry capsize kills at least 26 in Philippines

image.altText: African family on a yellow tarp on dusty ground in countryside camp with tents behind

items.synopsis: Two decades after Darfur became synonymous with genocide and war crimes, Amnesty International is reporting widespread killings, rapes and destruction of villages due to a power struggle between the Sudan government and a powerful paramilitary group.

title.children: Sudan conflict brings new atrocities to Darfur as militias kill, rape, burn homes

image.altText: Two men shake hands, one in blue suit and the other on the right in a black suit

items.synopsis: British media outlets, using headlines such as "You've got Mali", are poking fun at UK military officials who are investigating why emails intended for the US were unwittingly sent to Russian ally Mali.

title.children: British Ministry of Defence investigates why emails meant for Pentagon sent to Russian ally

image.altText: A soccer player wearing yellow and green sits on her haunches after a game

items.synopsis: The Matildas dominated Nigeria in almost every category, but what does it matter when they lost the only one that counts, writes Sam Lewis.

title.children: Should the Matildas' loss to Nigeria be a reality check?

image.altText: Composite image of two women and a man.

items.synopsis: Awareness of the Voice is low among newly arrived migrant and refugee communities, a survey by settlement service AMES Australia finds.

title.children: 'This is their country': Migrants say they need more resources to learn about the Voice to Parliament

image.altText: A close up image of a woman with an unidentified child

items.synopsis: The suspected murder of Perth mother Georgia Lyall, believed by police to be at the hands of her ex-partner, leaves those who knew her grieving and in disbelief.

title.children: 'You deserved so much more than this': Tributes flow for victim of suspected murder-suicide

image.altText: A row of heavily armed men in camo gear, carrying guns

items.synopsis: Yevgeny Prigozhin's attempted mutiny last month might have failed in Russia, but in Mali and a handful of other African nations, the Wagner Group's influence — and reign of terror — is expanding.

title.children: Over five horrific days, armed Russian mercenaries tortured an African town. Is this Wagner's future?

image.altText: Abbott gestures whilst talking wearing a black suit and dark blue tie on a committee bench inside parliament.

items.synopsis: Former prime minister Tony Abbott claims the National Indigenous Australians Agency disburses $30b a year on Indigenous programs. Is that correct?

title.children: We fact checked Tony Abbott on his claim $30b is spent per year by the NIAA. Here's what we found

image.altText: An image of a vast forestry plantation with a plume of smoke coming out the top.

items.synopsis: In an Australian first, artificial intelligence will be used in South Australia's Green Triangle forestry region to monitor for bushfires and improve emergency response times.

title.children: As an El Niño looms, AI is being rolled out in SA's largest forestry region to detect bushfires more quickly

image.altText: Josh hazlewood, in Australian cricket gear, clenches his fists and cheers in celebration in front of the stumps.

items.synopsis: This fifth Ashes Test at The Oval is no dead rubber, as every subplot and story that has made this series great comes to a head with the history and future of the game seemingly on the line, Dean Bilton writes.

title.children: The Ashes may be settled, but the battle for the narrative is just getting started

image.altText: A graphic image shows the Metricon logo in front of a house

items.synopsis: More than 60 complaints have been lodged with NSW Fair Trading since March, with Metricon listed on the regulator's complaints register for the last four consecutive months.

title.children: Investigation launched into Australia's top home builder Metricon, as more complaints emerge

image.altText: Two mature women in jeans and jackets photographed near a staircase outside of a courthouse.

items.synopsis: Station owners Debra and Chanelle Viney are jailed after attempting to defraud more than $250,000 from the Queensland government.

title.children: Grazier sisters jailed over fraudulent drought relief claims in Queensland

image.altText: Girl in silhouette watches sunset from rocks

items.synopsis: The United Nations secretary-general delivers a dramatic speech warning the heatwaves searing much of the northern hemisphere have been a "disaster" for the planet. An emerging El Niño means it may be just the start.

title.children: United Nations warns of 'global boiling' as July set to shatter heat records

image.altText: A rabbit.

items.synopsis: While two tourists are fined for taking their rabbit with them on an Easter trip to Kangaroo Island, a pet owner from the island has pleaded guilty over a separate incident involving two emaciated dogs, authorities say.

title.children: Easter beach trip with pet bunny on Kangaroo Island leads to $1,200 in fines

image.altText: An overhead shot of university students sitting in a lecture theatre.

items.synopsis: Universities have told a Senate inquiry it is not "feasible" to attempt to detect AI cheats, instead saying the sector will have to overhaul its entire approach to teaching to ensure students actually learn what they are meant to.

title.children: Universities say AI cheats can't be beaten, moving away from attempts to block AI

image.altText: Man in high-vis holds hose and nozzle as he refuels a truck

items.synopsis: The nation's largest supplier of industrial gas, Coregas, opens a first-of-its-kind commercial hydrogen refuelling station for heavy vehicles in the Illawarra.

title.children: Australia's first commercial hydrogen refuelling station for trucks opens at Port Kembla

image.altText: A smiling man in a suit and tie

items.synopsis: Lawyers for war veteran Heston Russell accuse the ABC of engaging in an "inexcusable abuse of power" by publishing "false articles" before using a "PR machine" to defend the journalism.

title.children: ABC accused of engaging in 'inexcusable abuse of power' by publishing 'false articles' about war veteran

image.altText: Daniel Andrews makes a hand gesture at a press conference. He is outdoors

items.synopsis: Daniel Andrews has used the controversy surrounding IBAC's latest report to take power away from local councils and into government hands, writes Richard Willingham.

title.children: Victoria's premier doesn't waste an opportunity — he has used IBAC's latest report to strengthen government power

image.altText: Sam Kerr looks to her left as she watches the Matildas warm up for their World Cup match against Nigeria.

items.synopsis: The Matildas are still no closer to knowing whether Sam Kerr will be available to face Canada in their crucial final group match, as their World Cup campaign hangs in the balance following the loss to Nigeria.

title.children: Matildas on a knife-edge as they hope for Sam Kerr's World Cup return against Canada

image.altText: A man in a hair salon chair holds up dreadlocks that have been cut off.

items.synopsis: Christopher Mark Jordan, 36, appears in a Launceston court accused of murdering a Tasmanian teen after the discovery of human remains in bushland this week.

title.children: Man accused of murdering teen Shyanne-Lee Tatnell named in first court appearance

image.altText: Australian Financial Complaints authority ombudsman David Locke.

items.synopsis: The financial ombudsman has experienced a record rise in complaints as Australians voice their anger at scams, slow insurer claims handling, and buy-now-pay-later products.

title.children: Delays in insurer claims handling and financial scams drive record rise in complaints to financial ombudsman

image.altText: A close up shot of Daniel Andrews face during a media conference.

items.synopsis: A proposal to host a regional Commonwealth Games at almost half the cost of the eventual government plan was provided to senior bureaucrats in 2021.

title.children: Victorian government ignored plan to host a cheaper Commonwealth Games

image.altText: man holding large spider

items.synopsis: Australia Post is trying to stop online retailers from shipping live bugs across the country in the mail after researchers raised biosecurity and conservation concerns.

title.children: The most popular bugs sold online hint at a sub-culture that's now under threat

image.altText: Anthony Albanese holds up his ballot while voting in the election that makes him the prime minister

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese will further escalate a high-stakes political stand-off with the Greens, in a move that could send Australians to an early, double-dissolution election.

title.children: PM stepping closer to early election trigger as housing battle with Greens escalates

image.altText: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese in a blue collared shirt and Akubra hat, standing outside and looking down.

items.synopsis: A report from the Productivity Commission has exposed – without spelling it out – an odd shortcoming in the Albanese government's sales pitch for its Voice proposal, writes Michelle Grattan.

title.children: This week we saw an odd shortcoming in Albanese's sales pitch for the Voice

image.altText: Aerial view of the Port Arthur historic site, Tasmania.

items.synopsis: A research paper finds World Heritage sites, protected for their unique natural or cultural values, are under extreme threat from climate change and risk being de-listed if those values are eroded.

title.children: 'Water is getting into these buildings': Sea level rises are hurting our World Heritage sites, research finds

image.altText: Zainab shown from the side, her hijab is in view and she's looking at the shrines.

items.synopsis: Each year, millions of Shiite Muslims flock to Karbala in Iraq to mourn Imam Hussein. So what does Ashura mean to them?

title.children: 'Bringing people to tears shows how human they are': Why millions weep at this massive pilgrimage
